title: Missouri Man Captures Video Of Mysterious, Cube-Shaped Silver UFO
description: Three years ago, Missouri resident Justin Johnson captured video of a strange, cube-shaped silver UFO that appeared to be ...
article_content:
iStockphoto

Three years ago, Missouri resident Justin Johnson captured video of a strange, cube-shaped silver UFO that appeared to be spinning in place in the sky. He is still looking for help identifying it.

“That thing’s a cube with lights!” Johnson shouts on the video.

After recording the strange cube-shaped UFO on his phone, he reached out to people who launch weather balloons and nearby air traffic controllers to see if they could shed any light on what he had seen. No one could give him an answer.

He believes the object was flying just a few hundred feet in the air, but when he tried to follow it in his pickup truck, it disappeared.

Justin Johnson isn’t alone in his quest for answers about UFOs that have been spotted in the skies above Missouri. Nor is the cube-shaped UFO the only time he has spotted and filmed something unexplained in the sky.

Seeking answers, Johnson uploaded his videos to an app that launched in May called Enigma that calls itself “the first Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena (UAP/UFO) sightings alert network.”

Enigma says its mission is “To advance progress on UAP using cutting-edge technology and social intelligence. Only through thoughtful, open-minded study of unidentified phenomena can we get answers. We are focused on building and keeping our team low profile for privacy.”

“The vast majority of sightings that we get are misinterpretations of something mundane,” Alejandro Rojas, a consultant to Enigma Labs, told KMBC News.

However, with nearly 20,000 videos and UFO sighting reports to review, Enigma isn’t ruling anything out.

“There are a lot of great possibilities out there. But we just don’t know. We really need to follow that data to figure it out,” Rojas said.

Johnson, too, isn’t giving up hope.

“We’re on the precipice of finding out something that can change humanity forever. This is all very exciting to me,” he said.

title: '68 UFO run-in at North Dakota air base still unresolved
description: Shortly after a pilot and co-pilot began observing a mysterious, glowing object, it rose quickly into the sky and disappeared.
article_content:
Editor's note: This archival article was first published Oct. 23, 2008.

MINOT — A routine bomber flight in the pre-dawn hours of Oct. 24, 1968, turned unforgettable for navigator Patrick McCaslin.

ADVERTISEMENT

McCaslin and his B-52 crewmates were practicing maneuvers in the skies above Minot, N.D., when officials at the nearby Air Force base radioed a request.

"The tower called and said, 'Could you guys keep your eyes open for anything unusual?' '' said McCaslin, recalling that flight four decades ago.

"We asked, 'What are we looking for?'

"They said, 'You'll know it if you see it,' '' McCaslin said.

"This is a dim memory," he added, "but I think one of the pilots said, 'Are the missile crews seeing things again?'''

McCaslin's first move was to focus the plane's radar into a narrow, high-intensity beam.

"I saw a (radar) return off to our right; it was faint on the first sweep and then it was very strong on the next sweep," he said.

ADVERTISEMENT

When McCaslin informed the pilots about the contact, they replied they couldn't see anything because of cloud cover, but asked him to keep them apprised of what the object did.

What it did, McCaslin said, was move faster than anything he had ever clocked on radar.

"From one sweep (of the radar) to the next, it came from three miles to one mile," he said. "Later, we computed the closure speed at 3,000 miles an hour."

From there, it only got stranger.

"It blew my mind that this thing had closed on us this quickly," said McCaslin, who recalled that as he advised the pilots of what the object was doing, the bomber lost radio contact with the tower.

"We could hear them, but they couldn't hear us," he said.

A short while later, the object dropped from the plane's radar.

ADVERTISEMENT

Officials in the tower also watched the blip disappear from radar and asked the bomber to fly lower in an attempt to regain contact.

This is a drawing by B-52 pilot Brad Runyon of a craft sighted October 1968 over the Minot Air Force Base. Bill McNeff / Special to The Forum

As the plane approached the spot where radar contact was lost, the crew finally saw something.

"The pilots indicated they could see it visually, just hovering above the ground," McCaslin recalled.

"They said to me, 'Why don't you unstrap and come up and take a look at this thing?' " said McCaslin, who decided to stick close to his ejection seat.

"I didn't know what this thing was."

Shortly after the pilot and co-pilot began observing the mysterious, glowing object, it rose quickly into the sky and disappeared.

Long witness list

While the bomber crew members were making their observations, workers on the ground were seeing something similar and reacting to alarms going off at one of the Minuteman missile silos near the Minot air base, said Bill McNeff, who heard parts of the story firsthand from a brother-in-law who worked as a security guard at the air base in 1968.

ADVERTISEMENT

McNeff, a retired electrical engineer living in the Twin Cities and a former director of the Minnesota chapter of the Mutual UFO Network, said the Minot incident was one of the things that inspired him to pursue decades of research into UFO phenomenon.His quest led him in the 1980s to the National Archives in Washington, where he poured over the files of Project Blue Book, the official U.S. Air Force inquiry into reports of unidentified flying objects in the 1950s and '60s.

"There were incidents (during the Minot episode) that did not make it into the Blue Book files," said McNeff, who added the official record doesn't reflect that two airmen passed out after a close approach from the UFO.

He said a report that the lid of a missile silo was tampered with was also left out.

"What I learned later is that the lid was completely off the silo and lying on the grass," McNeff said.

'Patternicity'

McNeff said the Minot case ranks among the most intriguing of all UFO sightings because of the number of witnesses and its proximity to a heavily guarded nuclear installation.

Those factors don't impress Michael Schermer.

Schermer, the publisher of Skeptic magazine and founder of the Skeptics Society, shakes his head at any suggestion UFOs are anything more than earthly events that have yet to be explained.

ADVERTISEMENT

"What the public has done is equate 'UFO' with 'extraterrestrial spaceship,' but to date we don't have a shred of evidence that any of the sightings represent extraterrestrial," Schermer said.

He said the Minot case, with its radar contact indicating an object that moved extremely fast, is interesting, but proves nothing.

In this 2003 Forum file photo, a B-52 takes off while another sits on the runway at Minot Air Force Base.

"How do you know it just wasn't one branch of the military not telling the other branch of the military what they're doing? That happens all the time." Schermer has coined a term for why some equate UFOs with visits from outer space.

"I call it patternicity, the tendency to find meaningful patterns in random noise," he said.

"Basically, our brains are wired to always find an explanation even if there isn't one," he said. "In other words, we have a low tolerance for ambiguity."

Vega schmayga

McCaslin, who eventually became a pilot and later a high school science teacher in Texas, where he still lives, doesn't know if what showed up on his radar that night 40 years ago came from outer space or inner space.

But he said one of the explanations the Air Force came up with - that his bomber crew was looking at a star called Vega - is hogwash.

ADVERTISEMENT

Well, he actually used a stronger noun.

And his irritation with the official story is still evident after four decades.

"My business was to navigate with several means, the star Vega for one," he said. "This thing was at or near the ground. How could it be a star if you're looking at the ground?"

When TV specials air interviews with McCaslin, his neighbors will approach him and ask if he believes in UFOs.

"I'll tell you what I tell them. I believe what I saw that night. I'm not ready to accept all the things that you see out there - about alien abduction and all that - because I didn't have that experience.

"It would be a leap in logic to say it came from outer space," McCaslin said.

"It could have come from inner space," he said. "It could have come from anywhere."

Scientist says some UFO reports worth pondering

Stories about a B-52 bomber's encounter with an unidentified flying object in North Dakota in October 1968 pop up on many Web sites.

In one posting, Twin Cities-based UFO researcher Bill McNeff relates what co-pilot Brad Runyon reported seeing in the early morning hours on that day 40 years ago.

Runyon described an object more than 200 feet in diameter and hundreds of feet long.

He said the object had a metallic cylinder attached to one end, with a crescent moon-shaped section glowing yellow-green connected to the cylinder.

This page on UFOcasebook.com details the 1968 UFO encounter of a B-52 crew from Minot Air Force Base.

Many scientists dismiss UFO sightings as unremarkable.

Many, but not all.

"My perspective is there's certainly something going on. I don't know what it is," said Bernard Haisch, an astrophysicist and author of more than 130 scientific publications.

Haisch believes the UFO question deserves to be pondered by the scientific community, even if 99 percent of reports are explainable or hoaxed.

"There's still a huge amount of data that is potentially useful," said Haisch, who operates a Web site called ufoskeptic.org .

He defines "skeptic" as someone wary of extraordinary explanations for perplexing mysteries who is also willing to look at data.

With the rise of string theory - which allows for the possibility of multiple universes - Haisch finds it odd that physicists are usually the first to scoff at the idea of visitors from other worlds.

"It's kind of a strange situation," he said.

Thomas McDonough, senior scientist with a group called The Skeptics Society, grew up believing in the paranormal, but gradually became a doubter.

"There are so many ways people can be fooled," said McDonough, who like Haisch is from California and has a Ph.D. in astrophysics.

Absent tangible evidence, McDonough said he has concluded that the Earth is not being visited by aliens.

However, he's keeping the door open to possibilities.

"Every now and then in science, someone comes along with a weird story that leads to something new.

"But most times," he said, "the weird stories lead to something mundane."

title: UFO Researcher Records 1,000 UFO Interviews From 1980-92
description: November 5, 2024. More for You ...

title: Donald Trump ‘knows our UFO secrets’ & can defy officials to release them – he must act to alter history, expert says
description: DONALD Trump has been challenged to 'change history forever' and come clean about UFO intel if he makes a stunning return to the White House this week. Arizona-based expert Nick Pope ...
article_content:
DONALD Trump has been challenged to "change history forever" and come clean about UFO intel if he makes a stunning return to the White House this week.

Arizona-based expert Nick Pope says there is growing hope within the global UFO community that if Trump returns for a second term, he will push through an executive order to have several classified files released.

5 Donald Trump, pictured on his golf course in Scotland in 2013, has been challenged to release any UFO secrets the government has Credit: Getty

5 Recent whistleblower revelations suggested the White House created a special program to track UFO sightings called the Immaculate Constellation Credit: Getty

5 UFO expert Nick Pope spoke about his hopes of finally seeing revelatory documents released that he believes could change history forever Credit: News Nation Now/On Balance with Leland Vittert

He also believes the recent whistleblower revelation that the US Government has created an "active and highly secretive" tracking program called the Immaculate Constellation could spark Trump's divulgation of critical information about the potential presence of other lifeforms.

SECRET REVELATIONS

Quizzed about his views on UFOs during his recent interview on Joe Rogan's podcast, Trump said he was told "a lot."

Pope, who used to work for a British Government department investigating the mysterious phenomenon that has enthralled believers for decades, is adamant the former president has been fully briefed and "is being cautious about what to disclose."

"There’s a strong belief that the US government knows something concrete and might release it, particularly if Trump regains office," Pope excitedly told The U.S. Sun.

"Many see Trump as a disruptor and a populist, less beholden to the deep state or career bureaucrats. Unlike other politicians, he could potentially push for full disclosure."

Trump has previously revealed, during an interview with his son, Donald Jr., that "he knows a few things" but had to be careful with the information.

Pope believes Trump is also determined to release the JFK files, which have similarly been shrouded in secrecy as the conspiracy theories over the infamous 1963 assassination continue to swirl.

"He’s already promised total transparency on JFK if re-elected, so it’s reasonable to think he might do the same with UFOs," the expert continued.

"SIGNIFICANT CLAIMS"

A whistleblower linked to the Immaculate Constellation case, described as "a current or former US government official," has allegedly written a report with significant claims.

It alleges that the US executive branch has been addressing issues related to unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) and non-human intelligence (NHI) without Congressional knowledge, oversight, or authorization.

Will Trump or Harris FINALLY reveal the truth about America’s alien secrets? UFO expert says one candidate will tell all

This situation, the report claims, may have persisted for decades.

There are also detailed descriptions of several UFO encounters logged in a government database.

One incident involved an F-22 fighter jet being "intercepted and boxed in" by a group of three to six spherical objects, which ultimately forced the jet to leave its mission area.

In another reported encounter, the crew aboard a Navy aircraft carrier observed a sphere glowing orange-red with a surface that seemed to be “roiling like the sun.”

This object descended rapidly from a high altitude, stopping to hover approximately 100-200 yards (90-180 meters) above the flight deck.

Journalist Michael Shellenberger claimed he had communicated with the alleged whistleblower.

However, identifying information, such as the exact role and gender, was being withheld to protect them from retaliation.

FRESH HOPES

If Trump does indeed defeat Kamala Harris and return to the Washington DC hot seat, Pope is hoping access will be granted for "clearer, longer videos of UFO sightings" as well as underwater tracking data, which insiders believe is also present.

Footage from military surveillance systems could also be released.

"There’s a lot we haven’t seen from the military’s surveillance systems," Pope continued.

"For example, the recent Chinese spy balloon was followed by other ambiguous shoot-downs, yet the government cited national security concerns as reasons for not releasing clear images.

"But soon after, they released clear photos of a Russian aircraft near a U.S. drone. This kind of inconsistency frustrates the UFO community, and we expect that a new administration might change this stance."

Allan Lichtman's 2024 presidential election prediction Renowned historian Allan Lichtman has accurately predicted the outcomes of presidential elections since 1984 using his 13 Keys to the White House algorithm. In 2016, he was one of the few scholars who correctly predicted a Trump win. This year, has revealed who he thinks will be inaugurated as the 47th president in January next year based on his system of true and false statements. If six or more statements go against the White House party, they are projected to lose the presidential election. Midterm elections: The Democrats suffered losses in the 2022 House elections, meaning the key turns false. (Harris 0-1 Trump) There is no primary contest: This key turns in favor of Harris because the Democrats got "smart" and rallied behind the vice president after Joe Biden ended his campaign, according to Lichtman. (Harris 1-1 Trump) The sitting president is seeking another term: This turns false because Biden suspended his re-election campaign. (Harris 1-2 Trump) There is no third-party challenger: This statement is true because third-party candidates like Robert F. Kennedy Jr. needed to poll at 10% nationally, according to Lichtman. (Harris 2-2 Trump) The short-term economy is strong: This key goes in favor of the White House Party. (Harris 3-2 Trump) The long-term economic growth has been as good as the last two terms: This key also swings toward Harris. (Harris 4-2 Trump) The White House Party has made major national policy changes: This key is also true, according to Lichtman's theory. (Harris 5-2 Trump) There is sustained social unrest during the term: College campus demonstrations have erupted in reaction to the Gaza conflict, but no protests have broken out that threaten the fabric of society. This means the key goes in Harris' column. (Harris 6-2 Trump) The White House is untainted by scandal: Despite House Republican efforts to impeach Joe Biden, they have been unable to pin a scandal on him. (Harris 7-2 Trump) The incumbent is charismatic: Harris is not considered a Ronald Reagan or Franklin D. Roosevelt-like figure so the key is false. (Harris 7-3 Trump) The challenger is uncharismatic: This key goes in favor of the White House party - even though Trump is a showman. (Harris 8-3 Trump) Lichtman warned that the two foreign policy keys - whether there has been a major success or no failure - could flip either way. But, even if both statements flipped against Harris, Trump would not have enough keys in his column to win the election.

Interest in possible extraterrestrial activity from political parties isn't new.

Marco Rubio and Tim Burchett have pushed for transparency in the past, while Democrats like Alexandria Ocasio-Coretz and Kirsten Gillibrand have also voiced interest.

UFO fanatic Robert Bigelow has donated millions to Republican campaigns over the years.

HISTORY CHANGER

Pope, however, believes a maverick like Trump "could make a real change" and push ahead with some seriously stunning revelations.

"Some feel he’s polarizing, but still hope he might follow through on disclosure promises," the expert admitted.

"People would remember where they were when it happened, much like they remember moments associated with JFK," Pope continued.

"And if there’s a backstory, such as humanity’s origins being linked to extraterrestrials, it could fundamentally alter worldviews, even presenting darker possibilities—that Earth might be a science experiment, prison, or farm, theories that would undoubtedly provoke significant shifts in understanding.

"The President who discloses alien existence would change history forever."

5 UFO expert Nick Pope told The U.S. Sun he believes Trump is a "disruptor" who will come clean about what the government knows about UFOs Credit: Getty

title: Mario & Luigi Spin Into Action In The Latest Brothership Slapstick Short
description: This one, titled 'UFO Spin', sees the pair deploy their new UFO move in an attempt to remove a runaway coin from a nearby ...
article_content:
Subscribe to Nintendo Life on YouTube 783k

We are getting ever closer to the launch of Mario & Luigi: Brothership on 7th November (that's just two days away!) and Nintendo is on hand to showcase even more of the slapstick humour that we can expect from the dream team.

A new video short is here and, just like last week's hammer-based shenanigans, it shows the Bros. getting into a spot of bother thanks to their OTT abilities.

This one, titled 'UFO Spin', sees the pair deploy their new UFO move in an attempt to remove a runaway coin from a nearby drain. Once again, there's no actual gameplay to be seen here, but if you need convincing that the series' slapstick humour is present and correct, look no further.

There are only a couple of days left before we can all go hands-on with this one and see what the series' first console release looks like. If you missed it, we shared our Brothership review yesterday, where we called the Bros' latest adventure "easily the best Mario & Luigi RPG yet". High praise indeed, eh?

title: I tried Hume's new AI voice app — it's good but needs some work
description: Just a couple of weeks after ElevenLabs debuted its generative AI voice engine that lets you create a voice using text ...
article_content:
Just a couple of weeks after ElevenLabs debuted its generative AI voice engine that lets you create a voice using text prompts, Hume AI is now offering a series of AI voice bots within an easy-to-use app wrapper that you can use from a web browser.

The app pulls from the company's own speech-language model, EVI 2, with additional LLMs used on a 'supplemental' basis, including Claude 3.5 Haiku from Anthropic, and feels positioned as a competitor to OpenAI's ChatGPT Advanced Voice model (which just hit Mac and Windows).

And, while I'm impressed by just how simple it is to get started, there's definitely some fine-tuning to be done with some aspects of the app so far.

I've been testing it with some general prompts and have found some of it to be genuinely impressive, while others fall behind.

Hands-on with the Hume AI app

Introducing the new Hume App Featuring brand new assistants that combine voices and personalities generated by our speech-language model, EVI 2, with supplemental LLMs and tools like the new Claude 3.5 Haiku from @AnthropicAI. pic.twitter.com/Tej3f7mBFWNovember 4, 2024

The fun of the Hume AI app is that it compartmentalizes multiple voices, each with its own tone and style to make it feel like you're choosing to speak to different 'people' for different topics.

There's one for quick, chatbot-style answers, for example, while another is focused on philosophical advice. Each functions the same way - you click, and speak through the mic, and there's no Hume account required if you want to give it a go.

I asked the Quick Answers chatbot how tall the Eiffel Tower is, and got, well, a quick answer, followed by additional information about how it's been added to over time, and how big certain sections of it are.

Sign up to get the BEST of Tom's Guide direct to your inbox. Here at Tom’s Guide our expert editors are committed to bringing you the best news, reviews and guides to help you stay informed and ahead of the curve! Contact me with news and offers from other Future brands Receive email from us on behalf of our trusted partners or sponsors

I'm definitely curious to see how things expand from here, and I think Hume has a solid base to build from if it can fix those minor teething issues.

I asked the Storytelling one for a story about a car, and while I wasn't expecting a Pixar-rivalling epic, it tripped over itself multiple times. It repeated lines, and even changed voice at one point which was pretty jarring, but it was happy to receive additional prompts to help direct the flow of the story (sadly, the story it provided, of a car called Cara looking for a power source, is unlikely to win any awards any time soon.

On the other hand, there's some overlap between some of the voices, and I actually found that a nice way of acknowledging there's no one true answer.

I asked the Spirituality voice how I could better live in the moment, and it suggested feeling the breeze through my hair, the sun on my skin, and that I try eating a mango, bizarrely.

The same prompt on the Deeper Questions bot prompted smelling my morning coffee, and the way sunlight hits a desk for some reason. Interestingly, the Deeper Questions bot, like the Storytelling one, kept repeating some lines of dialog.

I'm definitely curious to see how things expand from here, and I think Hume has a solid base to build from if it can fix those minor teething issues.

title: Anthropic unveils Claude AI desktop app with Windows on Arm support as concerned users pressure on Microsoft over a 'botched' Copilot update
description: The desktop version of the AI chatbot makes navigation more straightforward and seamless for users than the web version. Windows users can launch the app using the Ctrl + Alt + Space shortcut.

title: 10 Best AI Art Prompts and Templates to Unleash Your Creativity
description: AI Text Prompt Generator is intended to assist you in creating effective prompts for different AI art applications by ...
article_content:
eWEEK content and product recommendations are editorially independent. We may make money when you click on links to our partners. Learn More.

The best AI art starts with the best AI art prompts, but designing the right prompts to generate the output that matches or improves upon your vision takes skill, practice, and creativity. It’s not enough to just describe your ideal output—you also have to be specific about the visual characteristics you want, including mood, color, subject, lighting, and angle, and know how to continue fine-tuning and adjusting until you get what you want.

The best AI art prompts let you use the power of generative AI tools to create captivating, one-of-a-kind images. Here’s what you need to know to engineer them effectively, including prompt templates for 10 types of images, along with examples showing how the details affect the final result.

AI Art Prompts for Photorealistic Images

Photorealistic AI art images aim to create extremely detailed images that look like photographs, often with convincing textures, lighting, and shadows. They are commonly used for realistic portraits, landscapes, and still-life compositions. Photorealism in AI art requires sophisticated models to capture fine details, making it perfect for realistic simulations.

Prompt Template

“Create a realistic image of a [detailed description of the main subject or person], [detailed description of the subject’s characteristics and body position], and a [detailed description of the lighting, camera angle, and theme].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Leonardo AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Painting-Like Images

These images imitate classical painting techniques by incorporating brushstroke-like textures, blending, and soft edges to create an organic impression. It frequently resembles certain painting genres, such as oil or watercolor, creating a traditional art look. Painting-like AI art is perfect for achieving warm and timeless aesthetics.

Prompt Template

“Create a [ descriptive adjective and type of artwork], of a [specific setting with details about the elements of the scene]. In the background [describe any additional elements] with a [color scheme, lighting, and camera angle].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with ChatGPT’s image generator, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for 3D Art

3D art gives images a sense of depth and dimension as if they were sculpted or created in a 3D space. It is widely used in video game creation, virtual worlds, and digital sculpture. AI-generated 3D art can range from realistic to stylized, bringing dimension to flat images.

Prompt Template

“Create a vibrant 3D-rendered image featuring [detailed information of the subject], with [description of the subject background]. The scene is [description of the lighting, scenery, color scheme, and background].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with OpenArt, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompt for Animated Characters

These capture the essence of cartoons or other animated characters by emphasizing bright colors, exaggerated expressions, and clean lines. This technique is commonly employed in storytelling, game design, and fan artwork. AI-animated characters frequently appeal to younger viewers and have a whimsical atmosphere.

Prompt Template

“Create an animated image of [detailed description of the subject and surroundings]. And [description of the image’s lighting, color scheme, mood, and camera angle].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Leonardo AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Illustration Images

Illustration images are frequently composed of fine lines and defined shapes and are intended to be engaging and storytelling. AI-generated images are prominent in comic books, book covers, and website design. The style prioritizes inventiveness and clarity, making graphics simple to understand.

Prompt Template

“Create a detailed illustration of [detailed information on the subject.]. set on a [location of the subject]. On the background [detailed information about the background elements which include lighting and color hues.]”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Meta.AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Impressionist Images

Impressionist style emphasizes the essence over precise details, frequently employing brilliant colors and brush-like strokes to generate mood. Inspired by the impressionism art movement, it is ideal for capturing landscapes and evocative situations. AI-generated impressionist images exude a dreamy and creative quality.

Prompt Template

“Create an impressionist image [detailed description of the subject, setting, or event] with [detailed explanation of color scheme, lighting, and camera angle]. The [description of the location and the image’s mood].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Meta.AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Portrait Images

Portrait images focus on human faces, conveying emotions and personality in great detail. This style is widely used in digital art, character design, and realistic depictions. The portrait styles range from realistic to stylized, providing AI artists with a range of variations.

Prompt Template

“Create a refined portrait of a [gender of the subject and detailed information of the subject’s facial features], [detailed information about the subject’s clothing, jewelry, or makeup], and [detailed information about the lighting, camera angle, mood, and color scheme.]”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with OpenArt, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Surreal and Abstract Images

Surreal and abstract styles are otherworldly images with odd shapes, colors, and notions that frequently defy logic. This style can be thought-provoking and visually appealing since it can trigger different imaginative perspectives.

Prompt Template

“Create a [surreal/abstract] painting with a [color scheme of your choice] to capture the viewer’s imagination. Add subtle [contrast color scheme of your choice] for contrast and depth. The composition should evoke a sense of [abstract nouns] and draw the viewer in with its [striking/compelling] visual elements.”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Meta.AI, show how subtle changes in the prompts affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Cyberpunk and Neon Aesthetics Images

Inspired by urban and futuristic ideas, this style of art shows neon lighting, dark contrasts, and high-tech graphics. It frequently uses dystopian and sci-fi themes, combining technology with gritty urban features. Cyberpunk AI art is popular as digital wallpapers and video game graphics.

Prompt Template

“Create a vivid cyberpunk image featuring [main subject of the image] illuminated by [type of lighting]. Showcasing [a choice of element that makes the image stand out] [action word] [description of a scenery with color specifics]. Include diverse [scattered elements] interacting with the environment, such as [environmental elements] and [additional environmental elements]. In the background [add more items in the background].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Leonardo AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

AI Art Prompts for Seasonal Occasions

This style reflects the essence of holidays and seasonal events, with Halloween, Christmas, and Thanksgiving themes. Seasonal AI art frequently features recognized elements such as pumpkins, snowflakes, and flowers and is often used in marketing, e-cards, and holiday decorations.

Prompt Template

“Create a captivating [Event, season, or holiday of your choice] artwork illuminated by [ lighting color scheme]. In the foreground are [basic supporting elements], while a [detailed description of the image’s main subject]. In the background, [provide a detailed background description, including color and elements].”

Example Prompts

The images below, created with Leonardo AI, show how subtle prompt changes affect the output.

3 AI Art Prompt Tools To Consider

Creating prompts can be challenging, especially when you can’t find the right words to describe the image that you want to generate or aren’t sure how to make the tool do what you want. AI art prompt generators can help you create effective prompts—these tools enhance your creativity with the help of AI.

AI Text Prompt Generator AI Text Prompt Generator is intended to assist you in creating effective prompts for different AI art applications by providing a step-by-step process for prompt development. You begin with a base prompt focusing on the primary subject and action. Next, you refine your prompt by choosing from various stylistic options. You can keep your final prompt in history for future reference. The AI Text Prompt Generator makes it easier to create text generation prompts while also guaranteeing that AI understands and follows instructions correctly. This tool has a free version with access to 10 styles and four categories of action words to build your prompt. The paid version starts at $18 per month to access more styles and action words and includes unlimited AI prompts generated every month.

Quicktools Quicktools is powered by the AI photo editing tool PicsArt. This AI prompt generator encourages innovation in various contexts, including text, photos, videos, and code, and lets you personalize inputs by setting goals, contexts, keywords, and limitations. Choose the media type, describe your goal, give specifics, choose your desired prompt length, and let this tool generate prompts for your artwork. Quicktools is free and simple, making it suitable for brainstorming ideas for different generative AI outputs.

JuniaAI JuniaAI is an AI text prompt generator that can help you write effective prompts for different generative AI tools such as ChatGPT, DALL-E, and MidJourney. It uses advanced NLP and machine learning techniques to provide suggestions that assist AI systems in tasks such as generating images, writing, and concept generation. This tool allows customization based on your preferences, subject, tone, and desired keywords to make sure that prompts match your artistic style. JuniaAI has a free version limited to English language usage, and a ChatGPT-like chatbot. Its paid version starts at $19 per month and includes access to additional languages and premium AI models.

3 AI Art Prompt Courses To Learn More

I picked three online courses that can teach you how to create effective prompts to help AI models generate the visually appealing images you want to make.

Vanderbilt University’s Prompt Engineering for ChatGPT

Vanderbilt University offers this course on the Coursera platform to teach students about the patterns and methodologies for writing prompts adapted to large language models like ChatGPT. It includes a variety of strategies, from basic to advanced, such as a few examples and chain-of-thought prompting. This course is designed for those with minimal computing skills.

To access this course’s learning materials and a certificate upon completion, you need a $49 per month Coursera subscription.

The Complete Prompt Engineering for AI Bootcamp

Offered on Udemy, this course focuses on the practical coding abilities required to deal with AI models such as GPT-4, Stable Diffusion, and GitHub Copilot. It includes hands-on projects and focuses on the “Five Principles of Prompting,” making it appropriate for people who want to become professional prompt engineers. The course covers text and image production use cases, delivering a comprehensive education in prompt engineering.

This boot camp costs $119.99, which includes access to all learning materials and a certificate of completion.

IBM’s Generative AI: Prompt Engineering Basics

IBM’s course provides basic knowledge of prompt engineering for generative AI models. It discusses best practices and common strategies like zero-shot and few-shot prompting and provides access to technologies, including IBM Watson Prompt Lab. This course is designed for professionals, students, and AI enthusiasts, and seeks to allow you to efficiently use generative AI techniques in various applications.

The certificate and access to all learning resources are included in the $49 monthly Coursera subscription.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

What are AI Art Prompts? AI prompts are instructions or descriptions given to AI art generators to create images. These prompts might range from simple sentences to elaborate descriptions, directing the AI on the type of artwork to create. For example, a prompt may be as basic as “a sunset over the ocean with flying birds,” or more elaborate, such as “a futuristic cityscape at night with neon lights and flying cars.” What Are the Benefits of Using AI Art Prompts? Using AI art prompts provides different advantages, including improving both the creative process and the accessibility of art creation. AI prompts can boost creativity, allowing artists to overcome creative bottlenecks by generating new ideas and perspectives. They also improve time efficiency because creating art with AI is faster than traditional approaches. How Do I Get the Most Out of AI Art Prompts? Keep the prompts direct, use descriptive language and experiment. Add this phrase to your prompt to imitate a specific or popular art style: “In the style of [artist of your choice].” In addition, you can participate in an AI art community by sharing your prompt and your work and gaining feedback from other AI art enthusiasts who can provide you with other new ideas and help enhance your prompt creation.

Bottom Line: The Best AI Art Prompts Enhance Your Outputs

Creating effective AI prompts is important for improving and accelerating artistic processes. Clear and detailed prompts help AI models understand the artist’s idea, decreasing the need for revisions and facilitating creative experimentation. They provide consistency, collaborate with other artists, and considerably increase efficiency, helping artists achieve their artistic goals more quickly and accurately. Well-crafted prompts might spark new creative directions and innovations. Finally, mastering prompt generation is an important skill for any artist working on AI art production.

Learn more about creating detailed and effective prompts in our prompt engineering guide.

title: Not all the history inside the Dr Pepper Museum is sweet, it's spooky too
description: The Dr Pepper Museum is said to be haunted and long-time employees say they've had their fair share of bizarre encounters.
article_content:
The Dr Pepper Museum is said to be haunted and long-time employees say they've had their fair share of bizarre encounters.

WACO, Texas — If you had to think of a Texas soda, there's really only one choice: Dr Pepper!

The Texas staple runs a popular museum in Waco that draws plenty of soda-savvy connoisseurs, but employees say there's more bubbling beneath the museum floors than meets the eye.

With more than 250,000 artifacts on site, there's a lot to learn at the Dr Pepper Museum.

"There's a lot of different stories in our collection, there's a lot of rich history with the soda industry in general and we're able to tell many of those stories," said Rachael Nadeau Johnson, the Collections Manager for the Dr Pepper Museum.

Johnson has worked at the museum for more than 10 years and she is a testament to the fact that the history inside the museum isn't all as sweet as the beloved soft drink.

"Yes, it is some sort of haunted," Johnson added. "I guess I'm used to it for the most part. I've been here for over 10 years and we're all friendly. I say hi to them and just go about my day."

The "them" Johnson is referring to are whatever entities roam the halls and rooms of the museum. Making friends with the spirits, the ghouls, whatever old presence is trying to be relevant isn't the worst idea, especially with how prevalent they are.

"In several places around the museum we have little ghosts [signs] that say 'spooky spots' and those are places where paranormal investigators have gotten activity," Johnson explained.

One of the biggest mysteries is who or what is doing the haunting. Johnson believes it could stem from over a century ago.

"On the property where this museum now resides, it used to be several private dwellings and boarding houses, which is where we believe some of our activity actually comes from, not the museum building itself," Johnson added.

The second floor of the museum supposedly has the most paranormal activity in the entire museum.

"Why, I don't know, but it really is," Johnson said. "It always feels colder in here than anywhere else in the building. We have had paranormal investigators come and have a lot of experiences in this room. We have also had some people catch some weird light activity going on in the lights in the case behind me. Also, in this room it always feels like there's someone in here with you whether or not there is."

When 6 News visited the museum, Johnson said one of the ghosts possibly goes by the name Seth and is better known for its personality traits.

"Most of the information we get from whatever entity is here is usually it comes across as a young, maybe teenage man and a little bit sassy when we get our electronic voice phenomenons," Johnson said. "It's not a bad vibe. Like Casper or something, I don't know -- sassy."

Those lurking the halls of the museum aren't all friendly or sassy. There are some that are described as more eerie.

One morning Johnson was working in a third floor office before the museum opened.

"I shut the office door behind me, it locks when you shut it and I came back to the office door being cracked open, which was weird because it was shut and locked when I left it," Johnson explained. "Then, I heard people whispering and I said 'I don't know who's supposed to be up here right now, other than me,' and then the door slammed shut in front of my face and then I opened the office and no one was in here. Apparently dusting exhibits was just too much for them that morning, I guess."

Security cameras have also captured some paranormal activity too, like orbs floating in rooms.

"There are also some theories that we might just have some residual energy or poltergeist activity that was created by the 1953 tornado that went through the center of downtown and hit both buildings that are now the Dr Pepper Museum," Johnson added.

When visiting the Dr Pepper Museum, it's common for visitors to end their experience by getting a sweet treat from the soda fountain, like the world-famous float. However, there's an unpleasant presence felt in the soda fountain, too -- but mainly for the soda jerks. The staff working the soda fountains were originally called soda jerks because of the jerking motion they made pulling the soda fountain handle back and forth.

"I have not personally experienced anything here, but we have had soda jerks who have experienced things," Johnson said. "Some of them have reported experiencing their apron strings being tugged on, or their hair being pulled sort of like in a playful manner."

No matter where you go in the museum, there's a chance to experience a little taste of tension, but you must dare to step in.

"There are a lot of different experiences that people could experience specifically on the paranormal tour, but also maybe if they just visit during regular operating hours," Johnson added.

title: Ghost Hunting Beauties: Paranormal Investigators Bring Texas’ Haunted History to Life
description: Led by a group of fearless women from different backgrounds, each team member brings her unique experiences and a touch of humor as they explore ghostly realms.
article_content:
Houston, Texas – In the spirit of adventure and intrigue, The Ghost Hunting Beauties, a Houston-based paranormal investigation team, is stirring up interest in some of Texas’s most haunted locations.

The team includes Issa Medina, Angela Kaatz, Genny Murphy, and Lisa Gallo Roth. Each investigator hails from a different part of Texas but shares a profound curiosity for the paranormal.

Angela Kaatz, is the CEO of the group, she says she can feel and hear spirits. Originally from Dayton, Texas, Angela recalled her first encounter with a spirit at just three years old. Growing up in a haunted house, Angela and her daughter have shared multiple eerie encounters, including the sighting of a mysterious woman in a white robe.

Issa Medina, from Manvel, Texas, grew up in a family that strongly believes in the supernatural. Her paranormal journey began early, with sightings of shadow figures that led her family to bless their home. Known for her deep connection to spirits, Issa has led the team to some of the Houston area’s most active locations, including the haunted Hotel Grand Galvez, Wundertlich Farm, Montgomery Oaks Antique Shop, and the former Spaghetti Warehouse.

Genny Murphy, born in New Jersey and now a proud Texan, is a self-proclaimed scaredy-cat. When not managing her nonprofit dog rescue with 16 dogs, she dives into ghost hunting with humor and enthusiasm. One of her most chilling experiences happened at La Carafe, a historic bar in Houston where she and her team members heard children’s whispers and saw doors mysteriously close.

Rounding out the team is Lisa Gallo Roth, a skeptic from Galveston who now lives in Clearlake. Lisa remains cautious but intrigued by the paranormal. Her most notable experience came at the New Orleans Pharmacy Museum, where she encountered a setting she had seen only in recurring dreams.

Armed with high-tech paranormal devices such as EMF meters, REM pods, spirit music boxes, and the light-sensitive Boo Bear, The Ghost Hunting Beauties delve into each investigation with both excitement and a hint of trepidation. They encounter both friendly and less-welcoming spirits, sharing their findings on their popular YouTube channel and partnering with professional paranormal experts to deepen their investigations.

This team continues to bring haunted Texas history to life with every investigation, reminding viewers that, in some places, the past is very much alive.

title: With the success of Bhool Bhulaiya 3, let’s revisit the greatest horror content of all times
description: Bhool Bhulaiya 3 has cemented its position among the top blockbusters this year. The film has managed to garner over 100 ...
article_content:
Bhool Bhulaiya 3 has cemented its position among the top blockbusters this year. The film has managed to garner over 100 crore collections so far. We've rounded up five of the most terrifying and iconic horror stories of all time. These spine-chilling stories have left lasting impressions with their eerie atmospheres, unforgettable characters, and shocking plot twists. Whether you're a longtime horror enthusiast or new to the genre, these picks are guaranteed to keep you on the edge of your seat.

1. Yakshini… Ek Dayan (Pocket FM) Kicking off our list is the haunting tale of Yakshini… Ek Dayan is a Pocket FM original. The show centers around Yakshini, a cursed being of extraordinary beauty who ensnares anyone who crosses her path. Yakshini terrorizes the villagers of Bangalamuda and Rongkamucha, leading to the sealing of the Graveyard Kothi, believed to be her lair. For thirteen years, peace reigns, until Yug, a curious local, reopens the mansion, unleashing Yakshini once again.







Written by Anand Usha Borkar, and voiced by a talented cast, including Naaz, this horror drama keeps listeners hooked with its mix of folklore, suspense, and supernatural terror. Want to know what happens next? Tune into Yakshini… Ek Dayan on Pocket FM and dive into the chilling world of Yakshini.

2. The Exorcist The Exorcist (1973), directed by William Friedkin and based on William Peter Blatty’s novel, is a chilling supernatural horror that follows the harrowing tale of a young girl, Regan, who becomes possessed by a demonic entity. Her desperate mother enlists the help of two Catholic priests to perform an exorcism.







With intense performances by Ellen Burstyn, Max von Sydow, and Linda Blair, the film shocked audiences with its disturbing imagery and realism, sparking debates and even attempts to ban it. Despite production challenges and rumors of a curse, The Exorcist became a cultural phenomenon and the first horror film to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Picture, cementing its legacy as one of the greatest horror films ever made.



3. The Conjuring Franchise No horror franchise has captured the supernatural terror of haunted houses and malevolent spirits quite like The Conjuring. Directed by James Wan, the franchise stars Patrick Wilson as Ed Warren and Vera Farmiga as Lorraine Warren, real-life paranormal investigators who tackle some of the most terrifying hauntings in history.







The iconic characters delve deeper into the haunted objects and cursed entities that have terrified audiences worldwide. The chilling storylines, impeccable direction, and spine-tingling performances by Wilson and Farmiga make this franchise an essential part of any horror binge-watch.



4. Raaz

Bollywood's Raaz, starring Bipasha Basu as Sanjana Dhanraj and Dino Morea as Aditya Dhanraj, is a horror romance that left an indelible mark on Indian horror fans. Directed by Vikram Bhatt, Raaz tells the story of a couple whose marital issues worsen when they move to a house haunted by a vengeful spirit.







The film became a massive success due to its gripping narrative, eerie settings, and memorable performances, especially from Bipasha Basu. Its combination of suspense, romance, and paranormal activity made Raaz an instant classic, spawning sequels and solidifying its place in Bollywood’s horror hall of fame.



5. Ragini MMS Ragini MMS is a thrilling mix of horror and found-footage style, much like Paranormal Activity. The film stars Kainaz Motivala in Ragini and Rajkummar Rao as Uday, a couple who stumble upon an abandoned house for a weekend getaway. What follows is a horrifying encounter with a paranormal entity.







Directed by Pawan Kripalani, Ragini MMS taps into the voyeuristic fears of modern horror, making it one of the most terrifying Bollywood entries in the genre. The success of the first film led to the creation of the franchise, where Ragini’s ordeal continues, and the scares only get more intense. If you’re looking for a hair-raising ride, Ragini MMS is a must-watch.

title: Unleash Your Inner Developer: Create AI Tools with Zero Coding
description: Whether you're looking to build a simple contact form or a complex AI tool like a custom ad copy generator, VectorShift ...
article_content:
VectorShift has introduced a fantastic update that transforms the field of AI application development. This innovative platform now allows users to create advanced AI tools and custom forms effortlessly through an intuitive drag-and-drop interface, eliminating the need for coding skills and enabling users of all backgrounds to explore AI development.

Imagine building complex AI applications without writing any code. For many, AI development once seemed exclusive to those with technical expertise, but VectorShift’s update bridges this gap, providing widespread access to AI. With its easy-to-use interface, VectorShift enables users to create applications, from simple contact forms to complex tools like custom ad copy generators.

VectorShift Update Nov 2024

This update is more than just convenience; it fosters creativity and innovation. Through input nodes for data collection and processing, VectorShift unlocks a world of possibilities, allowing users to automate tasks and enhance business operations. With these new features, VectorShift makes AI development more accessible and engaging than ever before, providing a unique opportunity for anyone ready to explore the power of AI without the complexities of coding.

TL;DR Key Takeaways : VectorShift’s update introduces a drag-and-drop interface for creating AI applications, enabling users to build custom forms and tools without coding skills.

The platform supports the development of AI tools, such as custom ad copy generators, by using input nodes to streamline data processing and task automation.

As a no-code/low-code platform, VectorShift lowers the entry barrier for AI tool development, allowing users to create AI search engines, voice assistants, chatbots, and automations.

The update includes streamlined pipelines and a marketplace for cloning pre-made templates, facilitating quick and efficient solution implementation.

New features like Portals and Bulk Chops enhance model and automation management, while customization options allow seamless deployment and integration of AI applications.

Effortless Form Creation: From Simple to Complex

The latest update introduces a powerful form-building capability that caters to a wide range of needs. Users can now design:

Single-page forms for straightforward data collection

Multi-page forms for intricate, step-by-step processes

Customized layouts to match specific branding requirements

This versatility ensures that whether you’re creating a basic contact form or a complex survey, VectorShift’s drag-and-drop functionality makes the process intuitive and efficient. The platform’s user-friendly approach significantly reduces the time and effort typically associated with form development.

AI Tool Development: Unleashing Creativity

VectorShift’s update goes beyond simple form creation, allowing users to develop sophisticated AI tools. A standout feature is the ability to create custom ad copy generators. By incorporating input nodes, the platform streamlines data collection and processing, making it easier than ever to build AI-driven applications.

This capability opens up a world of possibilities for automating various tasks, including:

Content creation and curation

Data analysis and visualization

Personalized recommendation systems

The platform’s flexibility allows users to explore and implement AI solutions across diverse industries and use cases.

Explore further guides and articles from our vast library that you may find relevant to your interests in drag-and-drop interfaces.

No-Code/Low-Code: Bridging the Technical Gap

As a no-code/low-code platform, VectorShift significantly lowers the entry barrier for AI application development. This approach enables a broader range of users, including those without extensive programming backgrounds, to participate in creating:

AI-powered search engines

Intelligent voice assistants

Advanced chatbots

Complex automation workflows

By simplifying the development process, VectorShift fosters innovation and encourages more diverse perspectives in the field of AI tool creation.

Streamlined Development with Pipelines and Templates

The update introduces a robust pipeline system for managing automations and creations. This feature allows users to:

Organize complex workflows efficiently

Reuse components across multiple projects

Collaborate more effectively with team members

Additionally, VectorShift now offers a marketplace where users can access and clone pre-made templates. This resource significantly accelerates the development process, allowing for rapid prototyping and implementation of AI solutions.

Enhanced Features for Improved Functionality

VectorShift’s latest update includes several new features that enhance its overall functionality:

Portals: Centralized hubs for managing models, voice bots, and automations

Centralized hubs for managing models, voice bots, and automations Bulk Chops: Tools for efficient handling of large-scale operations

Tools for efficient handling of large-scale operations Multi-page form variants: Advanced input management capabilities

These additions contribute to a more comprehensive and versatile development environment, catering to increasingly complex AI application needs.

Customization and Seamless Integration

VectorShift offers extensive customization options, allowing users to:

Style forms to match specific brand guidelines

Add onboarding pages for improved user experience

Export forms as standalone links

Embed AI tools directly into existing websites

This flexibility ensures that the AI applications developed on VectorShift can be seamlessly integrated into various digital environments, maintaining a consistent look and feel with existing platforms.

Real-World Application: AI-Powered Ad Copy Generation

To illustrate VectorShift’s practical utility, consider the creation of an AI application for generating ad copy. By using OpenAI’s large language model, users can develop a tool that:

Analyzes input parameters such as product details and target audience

Generates multiple variations of engaging ad content

Adapts tone and style based on specified preferences

This example demonstrates how VectorShift can be used to create powerful AI tools that address real-world business needs, potentially saving countless hours in the creative process.

Embrace the Future of AI Development with VectorShift

The latest update from VectorShift represents a fantastic leap forward in making AI application development accessible to a wider audience. By combining powerful features with an intuitive interface, VectorShift enables users to harness the full potential of AI without the need for extensive technical knowledge.

As AI continues to play an increasingly important role across industries, platforms like VectorShift are instrumental in fostering innovation and creativity. Whether you’re a seasoned developer or a curious beginner, VectorShift invites you to explore the boundless possibilities of AI application development and contribute to shaping the future of technology.

title: Vertafore buys Surefyre to accelerate growth in MGA space
description: The integration of Surefyre's AI-enabled, low-code/no-code solution into Vertafore's MGA ecosystem is expected to create a ...
article_content:
Vertafore has acquired San Francisco-based Surefyre, a submission and underwriting workbench platform, to expand its AI capabilities and accelerate growth for MGAs.

Founded in 2017 by Alex Bautista and Dustin Lorres, Surefyre provides a cloud-based software platform for P&C insurance MGAs, wholesalers and carriers.

The integration of Surefyre's AI-enabled, low-code/no-code solution into Vertafore's MGA ecosystem is expected to create a better quoting process and policy issuance.

Surefyre's technology platform offers a fully configurable agent portal that supports the entire policy life cycle.

Additionally, the platform provides an underwriter workbench that rates and quotes specialty P&C business.

The AI-powered solutions include automated agent portal configuration, which accelerates speed to market, and other AI-driven features that streamline the submission and risk selection process.

Surefyre co-founder Bautista said: “Surefyre’s mission is to push the insurance industry forward with great technology.

“We are proud of our team and the impact the platform has had on our customers. Joining forces with Vertafore, an industry leader that shares our vision, is a perfect next step for our product and people.”

The acquisition of Surefyre allows Vertafore to deliver advanced automation and flexible technology solutions that MGAs need to remain competitive in this market.

Vertafore CEO Amy Zupon said: “We are intensely focused on empowering MGAs and wholesalers through technology. With the addition of Surefyre’s platform, we are setting a new standard for speed to market, operational efficiency and growth in the MGA space.

“This acquisition builds on the successful acquisition of MGA Systems two years ago and is a continuation of our deep commitment to supporting MGAs with technology that enables and powers their success.”

Vertafore, a North American insurtech company, provides solutions that facilitate end-to-end connectivity across the distribution channel.

Earlier this year, Vertafore announced that nine new insurtech companies and solution providers joined its Orange Partner Programme.

Encompassing 60 partners, the programme offers agencies, carriers and MGAs access to solutions and services that complement the Vertafore technologies they depend upon on a daily basis.

"Vertafore buys Surefyre to accelerate growth in MGA space" was originally created and published by Life Insurance International, a GlobalData owned brand.

title: As regulations proliferate, enterprises look to generative AI to help simplify ESG and GRC reporting
description: A panel at Workiva's Amplify EMEA conference last week discussed the opportunities and concerns around using generative AI to ...
article_content:
(© Khaosai Wongnatthakan at Canva.com)

The raft of new global legislation for financial, GRC and ESG reporting is putting fresh pressure on enterprises to consolidate and clean up their data and processes. Could generative AI could help alleviate some of this pressure? Companies are unsure about how to make the best use of it, and the regulations themselves are still evolving.

This was front-of-mind for delegates at last week’s Amplify EMEA conference in Amsterdam last week, hosted by Workiva, which provides a cloud-based platform for integrated reporting in ESG, Financial Reporting, and GRC (Governance, Risk and Compliance). The agenda highlighted trends for a rethink of data, reporting and governance. In this complicated market, where a mix of consultants, auditors and vendors all work closely with their clients, AI is beginning to have an impact — particularly in the ESG space, where data sources and processes are not as predictable as for financial reporting.

Speaking on a panel called ‘Can you anticipate regulatory change?' Andie Wood, VP of Regulatory Strategy at Workiva, told delegates that even the regulators are now trying to streamline the increasingly complex demands on organizations. She says:

Over the last five years there have been a lot of new regulations introduced, and the regulators are hearing from companies that they've been feeling massively under pressure as a result. I'm not just talking about one big reporting regulation, but that whole suite of regulations across the Green Deal and across the other changes in the environment. We're hearing them start to talk about focusing on the implementation. What are we going to do next? We actually saw the commissioners all being given the brief to specifically find reductions in the reporting burden. So we're very interested to hear what they actually think a reduction in reporting burden is. Everybody's getting themselves together. They're deciding what their new policy is going to be.

Undoubtedly robust data and processes will play a big role in the new regulatory frameworks, according to panel moderator Paul Dickinson, founder of CDP. He comments:

We talked before about how if you want to really make the best use of the almost unlimited, almost unimaginable abilities of machine intelligence, artificial intelligence, then you need incredibly good data benchmarks now to be able to take advantage of that in the future.

The growing role of generative AI

In ESG in particular, having robust data and processes is an important step towards allowing generative AI to play a significant role. Naval Khana, Director at PwC UK, says the technology could help companies meeting their commitments in updated regulations like CSDR and ISSB.

He presented figures to the conference from this year’s annual PwC CEO report, which found that 68% of CEOs think generative AI will increase employee efficiency, and 44% expect it to increase profits. In the report PwC says it is currently actively engaged with 950 of its top 1000 US consulting clients, and is now discussing its use and implementation with its audit clients. Khana says:

Everyone has access to generative AI, and this has led to an unusual situation, a democratization of a new technology, where personal use of gen AI, like ChatGPT, has come before companies get up to speed. It is unique and is having a mass impact, which corporations are looking at with a mixture of excitement and trepidation.

Generative AI is already making inroads in content generation, and analysis and interpretation according to Khana. He says trends like interpreting data from multiple media inputs using AI agents that can cope with text, video and audio inputs is having a major impact on efficiency. Domain specific models such as Harvey in the legal arena, and AI systems which use the ‘Human in the Loop’ models are also becoming more effective.

However, Jeannette Gorzala, VP European AI Forum, told delegates they need to guide the technology until they are confident they can use the models and mitigate any risk fears. She says:

Two thirds of employees are now using ChatGPT secretly at work, but only a third of companies are offering their employees guidance on how best to use gen AI. So there is a gap, a sort of limbo, and in order for the companies to get over pain points and innovate using gen AI we have to have a top down approach, as well as the current bottom up one.

Gorzala, who represented over 2000 European AI companies during the legislative process of the EU AI Act, says that the approach the Act takes will help organizations to scope their systems based on risk. She comments:

Gen AI will be disruptive, and there will be pain points in reporting, but data literacy will gradually develop and the use of gen AI tools in specific areas will increase, without adding any risk.

Different paths to adoption

But while these companies may need the efficiencies that generative AI based platforms offer, it makes no sense to start building their own generative AI systems from scratch, according to Simon Atherton, director CFO Advisory practice at Deloitte UK. He believes that it makes more sense for organizations to make use of software companies like Workiva that incorporate generative AI into their platforms. He says:

In certain areas like the front office, we all engage with organizations which are already using gen AI. But from a finance and GRC perspective, I think people are just trying to understand what the use cases are. My view is that most won't ever actually buy and build their own gen AI applications, but will use it when companies like Workiva incorporate it onto their platforms.

He draws a parallel with the emergence of Robotic Process Automation (RPA):

There was a massive trend for RPA software about 5 years ago. Everyone was going to use RPA. I actually don't think that many people in finance use RPA, because how you produce reports, how you raise invoices, how you pay invoices, how you do journals, needs the same organization. So I think vendors will build gen AI into their platforms. That's how finance functions. If Workiva builds something that uses gen AI, it's all about risk. Workiva will say, ‘We’ve tested this. We've got these protocols. This is what it is, otherwise you have to build it yourself.’ It doesn't make sense to build it yourself.

Workiva’s Wood says organizations are uncertain about incorporating generative AI into their reporting processes at the moment, but it has become a learning process. She comments:

There is uncertainty. To what extent AI can really draft? Does it produce a high quality disclosure? Does it produce a common disclosure? But certainly we see it being used to produce the initial outline and then circumstances. I think it's definitely already helping but we're still learning.

Gorzala from the European AI Forum believes it will be critical for companies to take their employees on that learning journey, if they are to use generative AI effectively and safely in meeting their regulatory obligations. She says:

The disruption gen AI brings will lead to innovation, and offer lots of potential to achieve more, and bring benefits throughout organizations. Taking employees on the learning journey is an important first step. There will be massive real time savings in the automating reporting of real time information sources, and using more gen AI tools for assuring compliance.

My take

Delegates at the Workiva Amplify EMEA conference are pretty fed up with the constantly changing global regulations hitting them. And whereas financial reporting has evolved gradually over quite a few decades, the ESG space offers all sorts of extra worries including the robustness of different data sources and processes they now have to deal with. One delegate told a panel she was tired of constantly thinking about risk, and wanted to start thinking about creating business value.

It makes little sense for these organizations to start incorporating generative AI from scratch. They should begin to embrace this disruptive technology as it develops through the platforms they already use. Suppliers like Workiva, and the management consultants and auditors who work in this arena, are ready to step up.
